Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Migratory Shorebird Response to Habitat Availability Dynamics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
An understanding of species-habitat relationship is fundamental for adopting a balanced approach for managing and conserving natural resources. This doctoral dissertation research project will investigate surface water resources and habitat changes over the past two decades to understand habitat resource availability for migratory shore birds. The project will assess broad and fine-scale habitat availability and will analyze differences between habitat types across wet and dry years. The research will contribute to a better understanding of natural wetlands and agriculture lands as potential habitats and the challenges of managing these water-rich resources under stressed conditions. It will provide new information regarding how spatio-temporal dynamics influence habitat quality and how public and private lands can be optimally managed to serve socio-economic and environmental needs. The doctoral student will work closely with several local organizations and nongovernmental organizations (NGOs) with the findings likely to guide policy makers in selecting and protecting fragile environments. Because shorebirds are among the most migratory species on a global level, the research will inform habitat management and conservation managers on a broad scale. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

Changes in habitat availability preferred by shorebirds are not well understood, particularly for inland wetlands and flood-irrigated agricultural areas. Because large portions of the habitat exist on agricultural lands, the synchronization of rice-field inundations with shorebird migration plays an important role in providing habitat benefits to the birds. This project will address two core questions: (1) What are the external drivers impacting long-term shorebird habitat availability? (2) How do these changes in habitat availability vary across spatial scales? The project will use multi-temporal satellite imagery, survey data, and in situ information for the Sacramento River Valley in California to quantify habitat availability in the area. The analyses will provide an assessment of the response of migratory shorebirds to changes in habitat availability, water depth and land use. As a key component, the comparative differences across wet and dry years will help improve monitoring and management of shorebirds and their wetland habitats.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Shorebirds are among the most migratory species on Earth, traversing incredible distances each year from their breeding grounds to wintering grounds, and back again. Over half of the 75 shorebird species in the Western Hemisphere are in decline, principally due to ongoing habitat loss and degradation. Climate change, competition for limited water resources, and other threats are expected to impose additional strain on these birds and their wetland habitats. Inland non-tidal wetland systems in are a noted research and conservation gap, despite the fact that they may become more important should sea-level rise eliminate coastal wetlands. The goal of this project was to characterize long-term inland shorebird habitat availability during spring migration, and to assess the response of shorebirds to habitat changes over time.

We characterized habitat availability during spring migration for non-tidal wetlands in California’s Sacramento Valley, a site of international importance for shorebirds along the Pacific Flyway. We mapped open water from February to May using all available Landsat satellite images from 1983 – 2015 and assessed how much shorebird habitat was present in managed wetlands and flood-irrigated fields. We found that there may not be sufficient habitat available at the peak of spring migration in late March and Early April. Flooded habitat extent on the landscape tends to plummet at peak migration, occurring on just 3% of the study area on average, compared to late May when extent increases by five-fold. The amount of water detected every late March declined significantly up to the present, with an estimated loss of 1,300 ha (roughly 4 times the area of Central Park) each year.

Shorebirds feed principally on invertebrates and water depth is an important factor determining prey densities and accessibility. To estimate the suitability of habitat, we mapped high-resolution topographic variation at 24 randomly selected managed wetlands in Sacramento National Wildlife Refuge Complex and measured water depth in these wetlands from February 2015 – June 2016. Assessment of habitat suitability based on water depth is ongoing. Preliminary results indicate that these wetlands, which are designed and managed primarily for waterfowl, typically provide limited habitat resources for shorebirds; they provide the most suitable shallow water habitat when wetlands are drawn down in mid-late spring, well after peak migration.

We examined the relationship between shorebird habitat selection and changes in flooded habitat availability using bird census information collected by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service at the Sacramento National Wildlife Refuge Complex from 1997 - 2015. This analysis is ongoing, however, preliminary results indicate that shorebird species respond strongly to the amount and configuration of water in the landscape and also cyclical droughts. Shorebirds are much more likely to be observed in managed wetlands when there is less habitat available across the Sacramento Valley. Shorebirds are also increasingly likely to be observed in managed wetlands at the refuge after 3 years of sequential drought conditions.

Funds from this NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Grant were used to execute field measurements. Mapping wetland topography and measuring water depth at fixed locations were integral to tracking water depth changes over time within wetlands as a way to quantify habitat suitability. We purchased water depth sensors and supplies to build customized housings to protect sensors in the field. Funds were also used to offset the costs of the co-PI’s travel to establish and maintain water depth monitoring stations and to map wetland topography during 2015 and 2016.

As final analyses are completed, results will continue to fill gaps in our understanding of shorebird habitat suitability over broad spatial scales relevant for wide-ranging, migratory species. Findings can inform collaborative decision-making with regard to water allocations and wetland management. Specifically, results can assist wetland managers in designing and managing water in wetlands with a greater understanding of implications for shorebirds. Findings would also inform conservation policy including payment for ecosystem services programs such as BirdReturns, which compensates farmers who retain water in fields during winter and spring to provide supplemental habitat for shorebirds and other waterbirds.

The Co-PI has presented significant findings at scientific meetings, as well as with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, non-profit Point Blue Conservation Science, the California Rice Commission, and local chapters of the Audubon Society. Three Duke Master of Environmental Management students have worked with the Co-PI on course projects related to this work, gaining training in remote sensing and geospatial analysis tasks. Feedback from leading researchers, managers, conservation practitioners and the public improved the research. As results are finalized, the Co-PI will continue to present research findings at academic conferences and will publish at two additional manuscripts. All data associated with this project will be publicly accessible from the DukeSpace repository, including water extent maps derived from satellite imagery, water depth sensor data, high-resolution topography maps, and models of habitat suitability over time based on water depth.
